docs.lead_paragraph: Critics of the Republican health care agenda say they are getting a little tired of hearing about the heroic-healer image of the new Senate majority leader, Bill Frist, a former transplant surgeon. They say that he may be a wonderful heart surgeon but that he is peddling the same old Republican free-market ideology on Medicare. Seven years ago the leading defender of Republican proposals to overhaul Medicare, the vast government health insurance program for the elderly, was the speaker of the House, Newt Gingrich, who was not known for his bedside manner. This year the Bush administration and the Republican Party have a smooth, empathetic, Harvard-trained physician to make the case.

headline.main: Political Memo; Weapon in Health Wars: Frist's Role as a Doctor

docs.abstract: Political Memo on whether Senate Republican leader Bill Frist will be able to use his persona as trustworthy heart surgeon to sell far-reaching, contentious Republican proposal to open up Medicare to more private health plans; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Critics of the Republican health care agenda say they are getting a little tired of hearing about the heroic-healer image of the new Senate majority leader, Bill Frist, a former transplant surgeon. They say that he may be a wonderful heart surgeon...

docs.lead_paragraph: The companies that provide discounts on prescription drugs for about 200 million Americans have refused to tell Congressional investigators how much they are paid by drug makers to promote sales of their favorite drugs. The General Accounting Office said the companies, which are called pharmacy benefit managers, obtained reduced prices for eight million members of the Federal Employees Health Benefits Program. But the keys to profit for two of the largest pharmacy benefit companies, Medco Health Solutions and AdvancePCS, were rebates and fees from the drug makers, the G.A.O. said in a report it planned to release today.

headline.main: Pharmacy Benefit Companies Won't Disclose Fees

docs.abstract: Companies that provide discounts on prescription drugs for about 200 million Americans refuse to tell Congressional investigators how much they are paid by drug makers to promote sales of their favorite drugs; General Accounting Office says companies, which are called pharmacy benefit managers, obtain reduced prices for eight million members of Federal Employees Health Benefits Program; says keys to profit for Medco Health Solutions and AdvancePCS are rebates and fees from drug makers; Medco and Advance do not dispute importance of rebates and fees from manufacturers, but insist that amounts are proprietary information and that they will not disclose them; pharmacy benefit companies are expected to manage drug benefits for 30 million elderly and disabled Americans under most proposals for Medicare drug benefit that Congress is expected to debate this year; critics say system results in higher overall costs (M)
docs.snippet: The companies that provide discounts on prescription drugs for about 200 million Americans have refused to tell Congressional investigators how much they are paid by drug makers to promote sales of their favorite drugs.    The General Accounting...

docs.lead_paragraph: In a lawsuit filed yesterday seeking $323 million in damages, the Justice Department accused Tenet Healthcare of submitting fraudulent claims to Medicare. Government officials contend that Tenet, one of the nation's largest commercial hospital chains, overbilled Medicare through much of the 1990's by submitting inappropriate diagnosis codes for illnesses like pneumonia and septicemia, according to the lawsuit, which was filed in federal court in Los Angeles.

headline.main: U.S. Files Suit Against Tenet Over Medicare Billing

docs.abstract: Justice Department sues Tenet Healthcare for $323 million accusing it of submitting fraudulent claims to Medicare; contends Tenet overbilled Medicare through much of 1990's by submitting inappropriate diagnosis codes for illnesses; Tenet disputes allegations (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Bill Frist, the new Senate majority leader, vowed today to reduce racial disparities in health care as a means of repairing his party's standing with minorities. Joining other senior Senate Republicans in presenting the first outline of their priorities for the Congressional session, Dr. Frist did not mention the remarks, widely viewed as racially insensitive, that led to the downfall of Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, his predecessor as Republican leader. But he maintained that it was time to address forthrightly issues of racial reconciliation that, he said, many in and out of his party have tried to avoid in the past.

headline.main: Frist Points to Racial Inequities in Health Care

docs.abstract: Senate's new majority leader Bill Frist vows to reduce racial disparities in health care as means of repairing his party's standing with minorities; calls for improving health care of blacks and other minorities, noting they do not live as long as whites, do not have same access to medical treatment or same doctor-patient relationsip (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who is seeking an alliance with local governments to tackle rising Medicaid costs, has invited the county executives of Nassau, Suffolk and Westchester to fly with him on his private plane to Albany today for the governor's State of the State address. Mr. Bloomberg will also attend a meeting with the state's 17 county executives before meeting privately with legislative leaders.

headline.main: Bloomberg Woos Allies in Medicaid Fight

docs.lead_paragraph: The 108th Congress convened today under Republican control, and the Senate quickly adopted an unemployment benefits extension after a partisan debate that some saw as a prelude to the next two years. After 11 new senators were sworn in by Vice President Dick Cheney and Senator Bill Frist of Tennessee, the new majority leader, took his place, the Senate sought to resolve the first of the issues left over from the last session, a $7 billion plan to keep unemployment checks flowing this week to about 800,000 people.

headline.main: Senators Vote to Extend Benefits for Unemployed As House Elects Speaker
headline.kicker: POLITICS AND THE ECONOMY: THE ACTION

docs.abstract: Senate adopts unemployment benefits extension as 108th Congress convenes, and some partisan debate on measure gives prelude to next two years; 11 new senators and 54 new House members are sworn in; Rep J Dennis Hastert is formally elected House Speaker over new Democratic leader Rep Nancy Pelosi; he and Bill Frist, new Republican majority leader in Senate, express desire to work with Democratic colleagues (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: On the eve of the legislative session, the State Assembly speaker today reopened the battle over rent control, an issue that held up the state budget for months almost six years ago. The speaker, Sheldon Silver, said he wanted not only to renew rent regulation, and quickly, but also to kill a provision that has let landlords remove thousands of apartments from rent regulation.

headline.main: Silver Pushes for Stronger Rent Controls

docs.abstract: New York State Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, on eve of legislative session, reopens battle over rent control, issue that held up state budget for months almost six years ago; Silver says he wants not only to renew rent regulation, but also to kill provision that has let landlords remove thousands of apartments from rent regulation; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Spending on health care is increasing at the fastest rate in a decade, reflecting greater use of hospitals and prescription drugs and the declining influence of managed care, the government reported today. The steep increase in spending has put immense new pressures on consumers, employers and public programs.

headline.main: Spending on Health Care Increased Sharply in 2001

docs.abstract: Government reports that spending on health care rose 8.7 percent in 2001, to $1.4 trillion, and accounted for 14.1 percent of total economy, largest share on record; rise, fastest in decade, reflects greater use of hospitals and prescription drugs and declining influence of managed care; Medicare spending rose 7.8 percent, while spending under Medicaid soared 10.8 percent, driven by increased enrollment; Democrats say data support their view that Medicare is more efficient than private insurance; Republicans say consumers had little incentive to shop for bargains in health care market because they were insulated from most costs; graphs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The largest union at General Electric announced yesterday that it would conduct a two-day strike next week to protest the company's decision to increase its employees' out-of-pocket health expenses. Union leaders said the walkout, scheduled for next Tuesday and Wednesday, would involve at least 14,000 workers and would affect many divisions, including appliances, jet engines, lighting and power systems. It would be the first national strike at G.E. since a 104-day walkout in 1969.

headline.main: Union at G.E. Plans Strike On Health Fee

docs.abstract: International Union of Electronic Workers-Communications Workers of America will conduct two-day strike against General Electric on Jan 14 and 15 to protest company's decision to increase its employees' out-of-pocket health expenses; strike will affect at least 14,000 workers in many divisions, including appliances, jet engines, lighting and power systems (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: If you work for the Nassau County government as little as one year and retire at age 55, the county may have to pay your health insurance for the rest of your life. That provision and others like it make Nassau's health insurance the most expensive of any local government's in the region, says a report issued here today.

headline.main: Nassau Battle Of the Budget Hits Benefits

docs.abstract: Nassau County Comptroller Howard S Weitzman says that county must cut its high health insurance costs to help balance budget; county's health insurance program for county employees is most expensive of any local government's in region; Weitzman says that Nassau's spending on health insurance has quintupled in 20 years and is one more reason that county nearly went bankrupt (S)
